Posts.Content: in_cognito wrote: Hello everyone.  I was diagnosed yesterday with invasive carcinoma.  The pathology report is not back yet as to what grade and other specifics - I just got the preliminary results yesterday.  I did have an MRI prior to my biopsy and it showed a possible cyst on my liver - I'm so scared that it's farther along than I thought.  The original mammogram and u/s showed my tumor to be 1 cm, now the MRI report shows maybe 3 - but the follow up u/s for my biopsy showed 1 cm.  So scared.  Meeting with all the other members of the team all next week.  Had a chest xray, awaiting results.  I have two very little ones and I am 37 years old.  No strong family history - I only found out about this by fluke due to a clogged milk duct while breastfeeding.  I go from being okay one minute to terrified the next.  Dx 4/30/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 2, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 7/26/2010 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 10/1/2010 Surgery 11/19/2010 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Dx 2/19/2014, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 1, 0/0 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 3/7/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 5/15/2014 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Chemotherapy 6/15/2014 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Dx 9/3/2014, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 9/22/2014 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Targeted Therapy 9/22/2014 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 9/23/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 1/12/2015 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Chemotherapy 2/21/2015 Halaven (eribulin) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday. Shock. in_cognito pupfoster1

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 08:06PM in_cognito wrote: It really is a tough decision to make and one that you have plenty of time to still think about.  I think we all look at numbers/statistics/percentages differently.  For me, the 3% benefit of chemo was a huge number.  I had a 1% chance of getting BC at my age to begin with so all numbers are out the door for me.  If I were single with no kids I may have possibly opted out of chemo, but would have probably spent a lot of time and research on it.  In all honestly, BC is such a crapshoot.  No one knows how the decisions we make today will impact our outcome in 5-10 years.  If you had a recurrance 5-10 years from now, would you regret that you did not do chemo?  I think that is the main question to ask yourself.  Lots of people do great on chemotherapy.  A lot of times, people that have the nasty side effects are the ones that seek comfort in finding out more information online or on discussion boards - so hearing about bad side effects seem like the norm.  Lots of people will tell you that chemo sucks, but is doable. You can also visit the YSC message boards - I think there is a category about pregnancy after BC.  You might find some help there.
Posts.Title: Chemo or No Chemo Truly Cant Decide jhalvors cookiegal

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 08:06PM in_cognito wrote: Hi nbills, The waiting is the worst part of all this!  As for your question about the tumor in question needing to be removed, I would want it out even if it was benign - just to make sure it was carefully looked at as a whole and not just a sliver of biopsy tissue.  However you can discuss that in further detail with your ob/gyn.  Hoping for benign results for you!  80% of biopsies are benign!  Please keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2010 01:32PM in_cognito wrote: Hi! I met with my surgeon twice before surgery.  Once to give me my diagnosis, then again to talk to me about surgery - then of course, a few hours before surgery.  I met with the plastic surgeon the week after I was diagnosed to go over options if I wanted a mastectomy.  The PS specifically told me that if I go the bilateral or uni mastectomy route with reconstruction/TEs to scehdule another appointment with him to talke about it more.  He did not want our second visit to be in the operating room.  I went with a lumpectomy instead.  I did get fitted for a post surgery sports bra (what I like to call it.)  It is pretty much a sports bra with a zipper in the front.  The funny thing was - all the associates in the store were telling me "Oh, this is what your surgeon loves for his patients to have after a lumpectomy."  Insurance only covered one of the bras and they were trying to convince me to buy another for when the other was in the wash etc.  . . It was $57 and I knew I'd only be wearing it for a month tops.  When I saw the surgeon the day of my surgery I asked him about how often I should be wearing the sports bra I was fitted for and if I should buy another  He basically told me any old sports bra would do - didn't even need the one that the sales associates were pushing on me.  However, if you do go with a mastectomy you will need to be fitted.

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2010 10:10AM in_cognito wrote: Hi Tori! I ended up having at least 3 areas of cancer during my lumpectomies - but only 1 area on the MRI.  They were all in the same area though.  My doctor is not convinced it is all out, so I will be doing a mastectomy now.  My doctor said they were all the same type and grade of cancer (IDC) and they would only count the largest tumor for staging purposes.  I had a 1.5 cm tumor and two other areas - 7 mm and 1 mm so far.  If you have two areas - one at 9 and the other at 6 - I am not sure if the surgeon can do a lumpectomy and acheive good cosmetic results - but that is something you need to discuss with them.  I'm hoping that the second area is B9 for you though!!!!!
Posts.Title: Lightening Strikes Twice... ToriGirl Suzybelle

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 06:10PM in_cognito wrote: My score is 14, I am 37 years old with a 28 month old and 3 month old. . .my stats are below. I will be going for a bilateral mastectomy now in a few weeks.  (The re-excision still showed a small lesion).  I am choosing to do chemo.  My Onc recommended it too.  In my Onc's words - "The data from the Oncotype research studies show data for 10 years.  We need to go 40-50 years for you."  While the absolute risk of chemo may only be 1% (I didn't ask if it was) - my odds of getting breast cancer in the first place at this age was 1%.  So to me, 1% is a huge number.  I will also do Tamoxifen when chemo is done and possible ooph after that 5 years is up.  I need to know I did everything in my power to fight this off to see my children grow up.  My Onc recommended 4 rounds of T/C.  I asked about doing CMF but this Onc said their pharmacy does not to CMF any longer.  Not sure if I believe that.  I am going to see one more Onc that has an infusion center located closer to my home than the first Onc so I will ask about CMF. I think your Onc would probably recommend you to do chemo due to the size and grade of your tumor.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2011 11:46AM - edited Jan 3, 2011 11:54AM by in_cognito I am a little over 3 months PFC and I ditched my wig on my return to work 2 weeks ago.  I was feeling pretty good about having coverage - as long as I had some hair I was happy.  And the reality is that this IS what I look like.  Most of my co-workers were very supportive of the "short do".  I have just enough to cover my scalp, almost an inch but not long enough for a short pixie.  I can tug on my hair with my fingers to give you an idea of how long it is.  I had long hair past my shoulders pre BC.  I work in a hospital so I do work with a lot of people.  Of the people that do not know what happened to me, they would look at me and gasp "What did you do to your hair?" or "Why on earth would you cut it so short?"  Some people would ask my co-workers why I chose to chop off my hair because they did not want to ask me directly, with the undertone that I am feeling as "it looks horrible".  My close friends and family have reassured me that my hair is fine and my features are so that I can pull off a short do.  But it was still a kick in the gut when I returned to work.  My patients that do not know me tell me they love my hair and wish they could pull off a short do.  Now I'm wondering if they are just "fishing" for a way to ask me about my hair.  I think they are being genuine though.  I think my mind is just playing tricks on me now.  Just when I thought I was getting some confidence, away it went. . . . .Anyways, not to be a downer on those that are thinking of ditching the wig but just wanted to give you an idea of how insensitive people really are out there.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2010 12:38PM in_cognito wrote: Hi frangipangi!  My kids are VERY young.  My oldest is 28 months and my other daughter is 3 months.  I was diagnosed when my youngest was about 8 weeks old, so still fairly new with all this!  On some aspects I am glad that they are so young - they do not even come close to understanding what is going on.  The oldest just knows that something is going on because I am away at appointments more than usual.  We also have more people over at our house than usual dropping off food, etc.  However, it scares me that they are so young, because I have a lot of years to go before they turn 18 and I want to be there for every moment of that.  Even more, actually!  Please let me know if I can be of help - or if you know anyone with similar stats as me that has already been through this.  Thanks!
Posts.Title: Any Mums with Teens/Young Kids? frangipangi juliaw

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 12:00PM - edited Jun 22, 2010 12:05PM by in_cognito Kim, For peace of mind I would say to get another opinion.  You can even get two more opinions and see if they all match up.  You have plenty of time to still do that.  I doubt the slides will get lost.  Mention to the radiologist that you are in the process of getting a second opinion to see what they say.  Getting a few more opinions will probably only set you back a few weeks.  With the mastectomy I would be inclined to think that the cancer is all out - the radiation is to zap any stray cells.  If it makes you feel better, we were diagnosed the same time.  I had a re-excision last Monday that showed more multifocal tumors.  I am now going for a mastectomy and won't have that done probably for another 3 weeks since I need to find a new plastic surgeon.  So you are still ahead of me in treatment Good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2014 02:42PM in_cognito wrote: My family attended a Little Pink Houses retreat in 2011 and it's very structured to doing activities and hanging out with other families going through all different stages of breast cancer. There are no formal counseling sessions during the retreat- it's mostly about connecting with other families as much as you want. You can choose to participate in all the activities or just do your own thing in your beach house. It's very low key, and I highly recommend going if you can.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2010 05:39AM in_cognito wrote: I do not think it is "routine" to have a PET scan after the biopsy.  I think Onc's or Surgeon's will only order a PET scan if something leads them to believe there is a possibility that the cancer is more advanced.  Usually, a breast MRI is routine and gives a better picture if it is localized.  Insurance companies do not balk at paying for the breast MRI if the biopsy is positive.  For me, I wish I could have just had a PET scan from the get go.  My breast MRI showed a probable benign cyst on my liver.   1st Onc then orders an abdominal ultrasound which shows 2 other lesions, which led to a CT of the abdomen which showed hemangiomas and a cyst.  I get a second opinion from another Onc about my treatment in general and decide to go with that Onc.  He does a physical exam and felt my liver was slightly enlarged and orders a PET.  I asked why the PET if the CT was negative, and he said the PET would rule out cancer .  So, as you can see I had a breast MRI, abdominal Ultrasound, Abdominal CT and PET.  It took 3 weeks for my insurance company to approve the PET - they did not want to because all the records they had showed me at stage 1, and according to the National Cancer Network guidelines PET scans are not necessary for stage 1.  My Onc had to call the insurance company and insist on the PET.  Perhaps if you have double insurance it will be easier.  Hope that helps - sorry I cannot help you about your question re: mammary. Good luck!
Posts.Title: PET Scan nurseronda10 in_cognito

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 05:32AM in_cognito wrote: Hi Swanseagirl, I was diagnosed 4/30 and going for my lumpectomy this Thursday.  I do not have a lot of advice since I am so new to BC but I just wanted to offer you support.  I am scared of having surgery and finding out what my final pathology is - but regardless, there is treatment for whatever the pathology ends up to be - that is what I keep telling myself.  I cannot control my emotions all the time as well - you are not alone.  What you are feeling is normal.  Please lean on us for support.  These forums are full of amazing, inspirational women!

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2010 09:42PM in_cognito wrote: Rest in peace, Elizabeth.  You are now reunited with your son.
Posts.Title: Elizabeth Edwards jleigh Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 03:15PM in_cognito wrote: I had a re-excision after the lumpectomy. I wanted a mastectomy but my initial surgeon was all about breast conservation. When I had the re-excision, I mentioned that I wanted a mastectomy a few days before surgery, but the surgeon advised me it was a bit extreme. After the re-excision they still did not know if they got it all. They recommended either watch and wait, another re-exicison or a mastectomy. I went and got another opinion and opted for a bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction. Everyone is different, but to me, not having clear margins the first time around was a sign to do the mastectomy. That was what I had originally wanted, and what my gut told me to do. I had to have re-excisions because I had little satellite tumors around the main tumor. Had I done the bilateral mastectomy initially, I would have avoided 2 extra uneeded surgeries. Good luck - it really is about what you are willing to tolerate.
Posts.Title: MUTIPLE RE-EXCSIONS ( after lumpectormy) Allenan Chrys23

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2014 10:21PM in_cognito wrote: I just had my liver biopsy done last week. It was Ct guided and they went in through the front. I had to lie flat for a few hours in recovery. The actual procedure itself was tolerable. The Radiologist numbed up my abdomen pretty well and they gave me something for pain and anxiety. The worst part was waiting for the results.
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: in_cognito wrote: devastated.  That doesn't even begin to start. Last week my final petscan showed large masses in my liver, up to 13 cm.  many masses covering all lobes. As well as skeletal mets in my spine, pelvis, hip sockets, femur. My femur is about to break they say. I started on radiation this week to my bones. My liver biopsy was Tuesady with results still unknown. My Onc wants to see me Monday at 10 to go over results. Is that a bad sign? Why couldn't he tell me over the phone? I'm 41 now, diagnosed at 37 with stage 1, IDC, Oncotype 14, did TC chemo and tomixifen. Also had a bilateral mastectomy but thats a moot point. have 4 and 6year old girls. Dx 4/30/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 2, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 7/26/2010 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Hormonal Therapy 10/1/2010 Surgery 11/19/2010 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Dx 2/19/2014, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 1, 0/0 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 3/7/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 5/15/2014 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Gemzar (gemcitabine) Chemotherapy 6/15/2014 Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Dx 9/3/2014, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 9/22/2014 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Targeted Therapy 9/22/2014 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 9/23/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 1/12/2015 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Chemotherapy 2/21/2015 Halaven (eribulin) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Newbie with mets to bones and liver. in_cognito RavenAngel888

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 05:27PM in_cognito wrote: Sorry you didn't get a lower score - but you are still considered in the low range.  My score was 14, which was a 9% recurrance rate with Tamoxifen.  I chose to do 4 rounds of TC.  I'm 37 and had a newborn and a 2 year old at the time.  I got two opinions from NCI locations and both recommended chemo.  I did not have any major issues with side-effects from chemo.  No regrets.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: If you were stage I, did you get chemo??? mdg SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2010 10:17PM in_cognito wrote: My OB found a small area of dimpling that was only evident when I was laying on my back doing the exam.  I never noticed it - but then again my boobs were going through lots of changes with breastfeeding.  Definitely get it checked out.  Not to scare you, but I did not have a palpable lump.  Please keep us posted, and know that you can come to these boards anytime for support.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 03:33PM in_cognito wrote: I had a lumpectomy and SNB in May of 2010 and it was such a breeze.  I was out of the hospital by 2 pm that same day and went out to dinner that same night.  I had incisional pain and just needed ice packs for a few days - no pain meds!  No drains either.  You will do great - the anticipation of the surgery is far worse than the surgery and the recovery.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 12:11PM - edited Jun 27, 2010 12:29PM by in_cognito Hi NorthernGirl! I had to have a re-excision a few weeks ago that showed another 1 mm of multifocal IDC.  I think there are still small multifoci left in there, thus I am opting for a mastectomy.  My breasts are dense to begin with and I did not have a palpable lump.  I had a newborn that refused to nurse on that side - which was my blessing in disguise.  I actually wish I would have done the mastectomy instead of the re-excision but my BS said it was not necessary at the time and three BS's talked me out of a mastectomy when I was diagnosed.  But now that there is more cancer they recommend a mastectomy (I've gotten a few other opinions as well).  I'm fine with that - I did not want to do radiation to begin with.  I am choosing a bilateral - I have two very small children, my breasts are too dense, I do not want to live in fear, and my BRCA results were inconclusive.  I have a strong family history on my dad's side - I believe I would be BRCA  3,4,5,or 6 once more research happens down the road.  Everyone chooses their treatment based on their personal history.  I will also be doing chemo - does my Oncotype warrant it?  No - but the Oncotype research is for 10 years.  I need 40-50 years.  I want to watch my children grow up, and watch my grandkids be born and need to know I did everything I could at the time to make that happen.  That is what my treatment decision is based on. So - I guess for most of us, treatment decisions vary by individual.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2010 03:29PM in_cognito wrote: Hi AStorm! I'm in Northern Ca too - right outside of San Francisco!  My Oncologist has the results of my Oncotype score - I just spoke to Genomic Health today to see when it would be ready and they released that info via fax/mail and email to my Onc and BS last Thursday.  I still have not heard or gotten a call back from this morning/last Friday afternoon.  So much for that.  Would you all be upset about that?  I actually am.  I guess it is because I work in the medical profession and know how it all works - to me it is unacceptable.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2010 11:50PM in_cognito wrote: Hi all - I got my oncotype score back and it was 14.  The Onc still recommends chemo due to my age.  He said that the research for the Oncotype is for 5-10 years or something like that and he wants me to go for 50 years.  He recommended 4 rounds of T/C.  I'm okay with that. On another note, my pathology came back from my re-excision last week and showed 1 mm of additional foci on top of the 7 mm from the lumpectomy that was a surprise.  The Onc recommended a mastectomy at this point.  My breasts are dense.  No one felt the lump to begin with and the mammogram barely picked it up so he thinks there could be more in there.  I'm 37 and this only came to be because I thought I had a clogged milk duct from pumping - I just had a baby.  So now, I am going to go back and read all the posts about bilateral mastectomies and the recovery, what reconstruction is best, etc.  Can anyone here shed some light on the recovery from a bilateral if you had one?  I have a 28 month old and a 3 month old so I am assuming I won't be able to lift them.  Any insight would be appreciated.  I would need to make arrangements for help - hubby works nights and sleeps during the day.  Thanks in advance!

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2010 11:51AM in_cognito wrote: Hi Ladies!  Hope you all had a wonderful weekend!  AStorm - I sure wish bad news on a Friday was prohibited!  I got my initial diagnosis on a Friday at 9:15 am - will never forget that day.  Luckily the nurse navigator was able to see me at 1 pm that same day so I did not have all weekend to think about the unknown.  You have a point - two breast surgeons told me I can always take more off and that a mastectomy really was not necessary in the beginning.  The PS told me to have a bil mx, but that is his territory.  I'll be calling my BS's office again today to get the results of my re-excision.   MRDRN - hope your pain is better now.  I had a lot of discomfort as well with the SNB.  Mine was mostly irritating because the scar fell right long the same line as the sportsbra arm cutouts.  It took a few weeks to where I did not notice it anymore.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 02:24PM - edited Jun 27, 2010 02:26PM by in_cognito Hi Zenith! I had a lumpectomy on 5/27 where the breast surgeon did the SNB.  For me, it did not hurt at all.  They do the painful part after you are under.  They did have to inject 4-5 little shots into my breast when I was awake, but those felt like little pinches - I thought a flu shot was more painful.  I also had a wire insertion - less painful that the original biopsy for me.  What they did was numb the area with cream, then looked at the tumor via ultrasound then inserted a fine wire with a hook at the end into the middle of the tumor.  I'm not sure if they will still do this with a mastectomy though since most of the tissue comes out anyways.  The wire guide tells the surgeon where the tumor is - so when the surgeon goes in he/she just follows along the wire.  There is a thread somewhere on this board called "Abbreviations for Newbies"  - I think it is under Waiting for Results.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 12:59AM in_cognito wrote: Thanks ladies, for all your feedback and links regarding post-op camis.  I am planning on asking my BS when I meet with him next week.  ctinas - so sorry that you are having a rough time!  The one thing I hate about this journey is making the decisions we have to make.  I hope you find relief from your pain soon - even if it involves removing the TE for now.  You can always take a break from reconstuction and go back later I think?  Catwood - I would be leery of anyone swaying you away from your decision.  Perhaps your PS was discouraging you from the TRAM because that PS does not have a lot of experience with TRAMS so they push the procedure they are familiar with?  Just my thought.  If you know in your heart that you want to do a TRAM I would find another opinion and find a PS that does a lot of them.  It is your body and you should be able to make decisions as to what YOU want to do!  I know your surgery is scheduled for next week and you do not have a lot of time - perhaps you can do the mastectomy and follow up with reconstruction later?  Or you can push the surgery back until you are more comfortable with your reconstruction options?

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2010 03:04AM in_cognito wrote: Hi Allison, Someone from the company that does the Oncotype test (starts with a G, I forget) actually called me last week letting me know my Onc submitted for this test to be done.  The person explained that my insurance will likely cover it, but if insurance does not cover it, they have some type of financial assistance.  The person from the company stated that my insurance is covering up to a certain portion of it - I may have to pay out of pocket around $400.  From my conversation with the person from the G place, they made it sound like I shouldn't worry about the costs associated if insurance does not pay.  It sounded like they had programs available to help.  That was my take on it at least.  Hope that helps!

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 12:18PM in_cognito wrote: Hi Sespebadger! I feel the same way as you - one of them has to come off, unfortunately I really do not have a choice.  This disease takes away so much from us doesn't it?  I remember when I had to stop breastfeeding because of all of the tests with injection contrast material - I was so angry that this disease was taking away breastmilk for my baby!  I had breastfed my first for 13 months and planned on doing the same with my second daughter but only made it to two months.  Now, this disease is taking my boobs away - which I've come to terms with - but the recovery time with all this is stealing time away from my kids, my job - the chemo will zap me of energy - my hair will be gone.  I am trying not to dwell on the sad parts because I am doing all of this in exchange for a long, healthy life - but it sure is a drag to have to go through it.  On another note - my PS's office called and said that they are more than likely able to bump up my surgery to 7/16.  Yay!  I just want to get this over with and go on to the next part!  Hope everyone had a wonderful weekend!  It is going to be 80 degrees here in the SF bay area!

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2010 01:46PM in_cognito wrote: Welcome Kate!  I'm glad to hear your NP took more action and did not just blow you off.  Do you have a lot of help at home with your kids?  I'm 37 and was diagnosed shortly after giving birth - thought I had a clogged milk duct - so we share a similar story.  JSmiley - Thanks for popping in and offering thoughts and prayers!  It means a lot!  Lymphtherapist - Best of luck to you tomorrow.  I will be thinking of you!  Regarding your question about the Oncotype test and CYP2D6 - I'm not positive that the Oncotype is done on DCIS - maybe someone can confirm.  My surgeon sent off my tumor to have the Oncotype done right after my initial lumpectomy - but I had IDC.  I do plan on asking my Onc about the CYPCD6 when I get my prescription for Tamoxifen.  I think it's a good idea to ask you Onc about that and request that test.  Robin - Welcome to the July boards!  What day were you diagnosed?  I was diagnosed 4/30 and have had a lumpectomy and re-excision which still showed more cancer so I am sitting here wondering how much cancer is still in my breast - byt the time I find out it will be 2.5 months after diagnosis!  I ended up firing the first BS because he was so blase about everything.  I know what you jmean about wanting everything out now. Rosesrx - I so hear you on the emotional eating.  I've been trying to do really well with diet and exercise but fell off the wagon yesterday.  I ate way too many cookies - my weakness! Clarity04 - I have not started Tamoxifen - I'm hoping someone else can answer your question.   I recall reading some threads where rash is a side effect - however I'd call your doctor to confirm.  Continued prayers for everyone!

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2010 10:47PM in_cognito wrote: Hi Astorm. . . I'm beginning to think I should have done the bilateral mastectomy.  My results aren't back yet from my re-excision - but I had it done Monday and technically should have had the results back by today.  No one returned my call this afternoon about the results.  Granted, he did tell me before the surgery "If I don't call you it's because I don't have the results."  That's B.S.  It's been 5 days now.  And to top it off he's on vacation next week.  I feel like it is taking forever to get the ball rolling!  The surgeon reassured me that a mastectomy would not be necessary unless the reexcision showed something weird.  I should have just done it from the beginning now.  I think if the surgeon tells me that the re-excision is clear, I will always wonder if he got the right spot that he was supposed to get. So frustrating!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 08:49PM in_cognito wrote: Hi Ladies! I'm wondering if I can join in to the group?  I had my lumpectomy 5/27 - I have to have a re-excision next Monday.  The surgeon got clear margins, but he took out a large chunk and they found an additional 0.7cm tumor next to my 1.5 cm tumor.  He thinks there may be another multifocal tumor so he wants to go in a scoop out some more tissue.  The MRI showed a 3 cm mass and mammo showed 1.5.  He thinks the MRI was picking up a total diameter of cancerous cells, hence the 3 cm.....  In any case, he said they would stage me according to my 1.5 cm tumor.  So here I am.  Does anyone else here have a history of multifocal IDC?  I'm really nervous about the re-excision - I have to trust the surgeon to be able to go in and get cancerous cells if there are anymore remaining.  Otherwise he said that another mammo or MRI probably wouldn't pick up anything small . . . .Ugh!  I'm 37 and have two little ones - a 28 month old and a 3 month old.  I had issues breastfeeding - thought I had a clogged milk duct and here I am!  Looking forward to getting to know you all!

I just do not have the recovery time or help available with two little ones right now.  I figure if I have to have my implants replaced 10-15 years from now - I can either opt to have them removed completely, or choose another reconstruction option at that time since my kids will be older.  Astorm - What a good idea - I think I will put my objectives down in writing just like you.  I am at peace with my decision.  However last night I just started thinking about the surgery and how I really do not want to do this at all (the whole breast cancer thing) - but unfortunately, I have no choice.  My moods have been pretty stable with these two little beautiful girls to keep me busy.  But late at night before I go to bed I think about how much this disease just sucks.  Redbarb - The little ones keep me very busy and pre-occupied!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 09:14PM in_cognito wrote: AStorm - I actually have a new PS - I met with one when I was originally diagnosed but am now opting to go with someone that I know.  I'm a nurse and picked a plastic surgeon that is highly regarded at my hospital.  I just have to keep my mind focused on his "reconstruction" work/pictures.  He has done "augmentations" on several nurses that I work with and that will be quite different than what I am going through.  I have a long list of questions for him!  I'm surprised that the PS you met with wanted to do saline - I thought that was rare! Shiela - Aww thanks so much for offering your time - too bad we all didnt live near each other! Can you imagine!   Family wise -  we really do not have a lot of family nearby.  My mom is close by - but she is 75 and takes care of my dad that is wheelchair bound and had a stroke 3 years ago.  My brother and SIL live about 4 hours away and I am hoping that they can help a few days during the first week - but they had a summer vacation planned and I do not want them to cancel their plans for me.  I have a lot of friends that really want to help - they all have little ones to deal with too so I am taking whatever help I can get.  Hubby's family is all on the east coast and unfortunately, they are unwilling to help.  They pretty much buried their heads in the sand - can't figure out why.  Maybe because they are too scared to think that this can happen to them.  They just act like the diagnosis does not exist.  Oh well.  The one thing about this is you sure do figure out who your friends are!

How often do you all see your Onc, Surgeon, primary doc, etc? Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2014 06:59PM in_cognito wrote: I had a pleurx inserted on July 7. I'm draining about 2000 a week now, compared to 3500 which was my average the prior 5 weeks. It is so much more convenient to drain at home. I wasn't told it was palliative for end of life. My fluid has been tested and it's non malignant.  The insertion itself was an easy process, Same day procedure. The draining process is pretty easy too. Just make sure you wash your hands really well and follow the instructions given to you. I'm glad I got mine. I was so uncomfortable before I had it put in.

I was just diagnosed with mets in February after being stage 1 just 4 years ago. Still trying to wrap my head around all this. Debating if I need to start writing letters to them. Some days I think I will live forever, and days where I'm wiped out makes me start going down that rabbit hole. Anyways glad you started this thread.
Posts.Title: Mothers with school aged children Kjones13 Kjones13

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 02:10PM in_cognito wrote: Hi everyone - a nurse here with bc too!  I've been a nurse for 5 years now - went to nursing school at 30 after working in the business world.  I work on a telemetry floor as a staff nurse and relief charge nurse.  I work PM's - have been on disability since February of this year - went on maternity leave, now I will be taking more disability to deal with this horrendous disease.  I also work per-diem at Children's hospital in utilization review - it's eye opening seeing what insurance companies nit pick about.  Hoopefully we can get this thread going - will read the last 10 pages as well!
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 09:45PM in_cognito wrote: HI ladies! I tried to go back a few pages to see if this was mentioned - but I am wondering if any of you ladies had a BMX with TE's - if so, when did you return to work after surgery?  My surgery is scheduled 11/11 and so far, my return to work is anticipated around the end of December (6 weeks off).   I made this timeframe up in my head.   I asked my PS when he thought I could go back to work and he just kind of shrugged and said "Let's just play it by ear".  He said he wants me moving for sure, but not heavy lifting and said we will see how it goes.  On average, when did you return to bedside care after a BMX with TE's?  Thanks for your help!
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 11:00AM in_cognito wrote: Cheers - what kind of restrictions did your Onc write up for you?  Are they mainly for lifting? My Onc recommends I not work throughout chemo as I work in acute care on the floor.  I've been of work since February - diagnosed in April.  I was diagnosed on maternity leave, so the doctors have written me off work to heal from the lumpectomies because I got jipped of maternity leave.  I will be having a BMX in a few weeks.  I do not anticipate going back to work until January.  I'm hoping I can just resume work as normal after this is said and done.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 09:46AM - edited Jan 23, 2011 09:47AM by in_cognito Hi Nicole - They are not supposed to add the tumors together - staging is based on the largest tumor size.  There was a research study report I was reading that said that we should move towards adding the tumors up in node positive women, but since I was node negative I did not save the report.  I choose to keep my head buried in the sand as I had multifocal tumors.  I had a lumpectomy and re-excision and went back for a BMX after chemo.
